program_name: Grab and Go: Wianek Flower Crown
program_description: Celebrate Polish American Heritage Month by making a Wianek, or flower crown. A Wianek is an accessory that is worn in Poland for special occasions such as holidays, parades, weddings and other festivals.  Our grab and go kit has everything you need to make your own Wianek Flower Crown! Stop by the Jefferson Park Branch to pick up a kit during regular library hours, while supplies last.

Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. When visiting the library, maintain at least six feet of distance from staff and other patrons. Stay home if you or someone in your group are experiencing symptoms of any illness per order of the Chicago Department of Public Health.Questions about visiting the library? Check out our Using the Library FAQ.

program_name: Neighborhood Tour: Postcards From The Past
program_description: What do Chicago’s postcards tell us about the past? Or the present? Or how a community has changed? In this walk, we’ll look at 7-9 different sites to look carefully at how these places have changed since they were depicted within the postcards - it’ll be an opportunity to think about changes in the urban environment - modest and major. Join us for virtual neighborhood tours, featuring host and urbanologist Max Grinnell, as we explore the people, places and communities that make Chicago's neighborhoods so special! How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.AccessibilityAutomatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Get to Work with the ICNC
program_description: Industrial Council of Nearwest Chicago (ICNC) will provide job seekers access to job opportunities and coaching on job search techniques and resumes. In addition, they can refer individuals to job training providers and small business resources.ICNC is a partner of The Hatchery Chicago. Together they will be offering a culinary training program for young adults. ICNC works with start-ups and established businesses in industries such as manufacturing, food/beverage, apparel/textiles and more. Registration is recommended but not required.How to AttendThis is an in person event. program_name: The Quiet Year – Community Storytelling and Mapmaking Game
program_description: Using gameplay as a means of building community, join the library as we explore and play the critically acclaimed storytelling and cartography game The Quiet Year by designer Avery Alder.  The Quiet Year is a unique game built around map making and community life after a devastating event. Players will use a deck of cards that correspond to weeks of the year, with each card representing one week.  Each week brings questions and decisions driven by luck, omens, and other elements that affect everyone and everything in the fictional community being built.  Each of these elements are then added to a map which takes shape over the course of the year.  By the end of the game, players will have collaboratively told the story one year of community life and represented it on a shared map.  No need for roleplaying game experience to join, though this program is aimed towards teen and adult audiences.How to Attend:This game will take place virtually. You will need to download free Zoom software. Advance registration is required. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4072 or email access@chipublib.org. Requests for live captioning must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: From Sarah to Sydney: A Conversation with Alexandra Dunietz
program_description: From Sarah to Sydney by the late June Cummins, is the untold life story of the All-Of-A-Kind Family author Sydney Taylor, highlighting her dramatic influence on American children’s literature. The All-Of-A-Kind Family series, beloved by generations of readers, are the first juvenile novels published by a mainstream publisher to feature Jewish children. The family—based on Taylor’s own as a child—includes five sisters, each two years apart, dressed alike by their fastidious immigrant mother so they all look the same: all-of-a-kind.Cummins elucidates the deep connections between the progressive Taylor’s books and American Jewish experiences, arguing that Taylor was deeply influential in the development of a national Jewish identity. The biography conveys the vital importance of children’s books in the transmission of Jewish culture and the preservation of ethnic heritage.Cummins friend and co-author, Alexandra Dunietz, will present followed by a post-lecture Q & A.June Cummins was professor emerita of English and comparative literature at San Diego State University, where  she made important contributions to its National Center for the Study of Children's Literature.Alexandra Dunietz is a historian of the medieval Middle East.This program is a collaboration between the Selfhelp Home, the Skokie Public Library, The Village Chicago and the Chicago Public Library.Program registration includes a 25% discount on the purchase of the book from Yale University Press using discount code YEFSS.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. Sphero robots are a great tool for learning some of the basics of computer coding and programming. If you've ever wondered what it's like to write code, drop by the 3rd Floor of the Harold Washington library and get an in person demo of the Sphero Bot in action. The bots roll around, take directional commands, light up, even make animal sounds on command!In this program attendees will learn to navigate the Sphero bot using the basics of vector programming, also known as "Turtle Graphics." Patrons will also learn about ways to simplify code with the use of loops, and get some experience with step by step computational thinking. The workshop will culminate in navigating the sphero through a maze with various layers of challenge.This program is designed with a casual "drop-in" style of learning. The instruction start-to-finish should take about 10-15 minutes, and allow patrons some room to experiment and explore the coding aspect in their own way.No registration required. Just come to the 3rd Floor of the Harold Washington Library Center at noon on October 21.

program_name: The Value of Community with DePaul University
program_description: In Bedrock Faith, the 2021 One Book, One Chicago selection, community ties are tested and triumph over questions of faith, fear, and forgiveness. Join DePaul University professors Dr. Rita Mookerjee,  Dr. Megan Alderden and Dan Stolar to listen and ask questions throughout a discussion exploring community’s place in the classroom and across academic pursuits. This diverse discussion aims to bring us together and remind us to appreciate where we come from, and where we’re going.  Dr. Rita Mookerjee is the Ida B. Wells-Barnett Fellow in the African and Black Diaspora Studies Department at DePaul University. Her research areas include contemporary Caribbean literature, gender theory, intersectional feminisms, and food studies. In 2020, she was a Fulbright fellow in Kingston, Jamaica. She is the co-founder of Honey Literary, a BIPOC and queer-centric journal of art and writing, and also serves as the Assistant Poetry Editor at Split Lip Magazine.Dr. Megan Alderden is an Associate Professor and Director of Criminology at DePaul University. Dr. Alderden has over 20 years of experience conducting criminal justice-related research as well as implementation and outcome evaluations of criminal justice programs. Dr. Alderden’s work includes examining issues within the field of victimology and policing. She worked on two National Institute of Justice funded research studies examining the impact of forensic evidence on police and prosecutorial decisions in sexual assault cases, and was researcher with the National Police Research Platform, where her work focused on police diversification, police culture, and the civilianization of police agencies. She is currently an evaluator of a federally funded reentry program in Chicago and Cook County that focuses on job training and reentry support for individuals post incarceration.Dan Stolar is the author of a collection of short stories, The Middle of the Night (Picador). His fiction and creative nonfiction have appeared in a numerous publications including, The Virginia Quarterly Review, The Missouri Review, Bomb, the Utne Reader and the Chicago Tribune. He’s an associate professor at DePaul University.How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. You'll be able to ask questions during the event as well!Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.AccessibilityAutomatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. A frightening delinquent before being sent away, his neighbors are more than a little nervous about his return--even after he has let it be known that he has had a religious conversion.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Adult Crafting: Learn Origami with Esteban
program_description: Join the North Pulaski Branch and our neighborhood origami man, Esteban, to learn origami basics. Esteban will lead us through everything from the beginner's crane to more medium/intermediate animals and even some Halloween inspired origami. Please visit North Pulaski for a grab and go kit for a set of pre-cut 8" x 8" paper for the origami sessions, while supplies last. If you would like a kit sent to your local branch, please email John and let him know how many and which branch. Each kit will contain 10 sheets of paper (limit 5).  If you'd like to use your own paper at home, please cut 8" x 8" squares to begin. How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Private Eye Book Club: Children of Chicago by Cynthia Pelayo
program_description: Join the Private Eye Book Club for our discussion of Children of Chicago, the latest novel by local poet Cynthia Pelayo. Just in time for both Latinx History Month and Halloween, this eerie, Chicago-set mystery combines police procedurals and horror fiction with an exploration of the power of fairy tales. Pelayo is the author of poetry collections Poems of My Night and Into the Forest and All the Way Through.Participants should remember to check their "Spam"/"Bulk" or "Junk" folders if they do not see their Zoom invitations in their inboxes after they have registered, as email settings may affect how invitations are received.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Weekly Cinema at Vodak East-Side!Join us throughout the month of October as we get into the spooky spirit of Halloween with movies filled with horror, suspense, and thrills!Our chilling selection for this week is a double-feature: Halloweentown & Halloweentown II: Kalabar's Revenge.Halloweentown: Thanks to a visit from Grandmother Aggie, Marnie and her family's tradition of ignoring the Halloween holiday are about to change in the extreme. It seems that Marnie's mother Gwen has been hiding a big secret from her three children--all of them possess supernatural powers.Halloweentown II: Kalabar's son is bent on revenge. Marnie has matured as a witch, but her powers are pushed to the limit in a desperate effort to triumph over an evil curse in order to save Halloweentown, her family and the human world.© Walt Disney Pictures - 180 Minutes - Rated G

Join us at the Roden Branch for a screening of Disney's Cruella.Emma Stone (LA LA LAND) stars in Disney’s CRUELLA, a live-action feature film about the rebellious early days of one of cinema’s most notorious – and notoriously fashionable – villains, the legendary Cruella de Vil. Set during the 1970s punk rock revolution in London, the story follows a clever and creative young grifter named Estella, who is determined to become a successful designer. After Estella befriends a pair of young thieves who appreciate her appetite for mischief, the three build a life for themselves on the London streets. Before long, Estella’s flair for fashion catches the eye of the Baroness von Hellman, a devastatingly chic and terrifyingly haute fashion legend, played by Emma Thompson (HOWARDS END, SENSE AND SENSIBILITY). But their relationship sets in motion a course of events and revelations that will cause Estella to embrace her wicked side and become the raucous, fashionable and revenge-bent Cruella.© Walt Disney Pictures-134 Min.-Rated PG-13How to Attend:This event will happen in person at the branch. COVID-19 safety protocols will be followed, including masks and social distancing. Advance registration is required to ensure a safe event.AccessibilityNeed captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 10 business days before the event.

For Latinx Heritage Month, South Chicago Branch will be reading The Alchemist by Paulo Coelho.Paulo Coelho's enchanting novel has inspired a devoted following around the world. This story, dazzling in its powerful simplicity and soul-stirring wisdom, is about an Andalusian shepherd boy named Santiago who travels from his homeland in Spain to the Egyptian desert in search of a treasure buried near the Pyramids. Along the way he meets a Gypsy woman, a man who calls himself king, and an alchemist, all of whom point Santiago in the direction of his quest. No one knows what the treasure is, or if Santiago will be able to surmount the obstacles in his path. But what starts out as a journey to find worldly goods turns into a discovery of the treasure found within. Lush, evocative, and deeply humane, the story of Santiago is an eternal testament to the transforming power of our dreams and the importance of listening to our hearts (Goodreads, 2021).  How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. You'll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. By registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines. This event uses a third-party website and may be hosted by an organization CPL has partnered with. Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. program_name: Grab and Go: Wianek Flower Crown
program_description: Celebrate Polish American Heritage Month by making a Wianek, or flower crown. A Wianek is an accessory that is worn in Poland for special occasions such as holidays, parades, weddings and other festivals.  Our grab and go kit has everything you need to make your own Wianek Flower Crown! Stop by the North Austin Branch to pick up a kit during regular branch hours, while supplies last.

program_name: Whose Lakefront: Chicago's Unceded Native Land
program_description: Learn about the history and occupation of Indigenous land by marking the presence of unceded territory in the heart of Chicago’s downtown. The “Whose Lakefront”  project is based on a 1914 lawsuit brought by the Pokagon Band of Potawatomi Indians against Chicago for land along the lakefront. Members of the Pokagon Band, based in Michigan, along with a Native resident of Chicago and non-Native ally will discuss this history and contemporary Native sovereignty as highlighted through a recent public art project marking this unceded territory in the heart of Chicago's downtown.  Panelists include JeeYeun Lee, John Low, Madolyn Wesaw, and Debra Yepa-Pappan. This program is co-sponsored by CPL’s Native American Heritage Committee. JeeYeun Lee is an interdisciplinary artist, writer, and activist whose work explores issues of power, connection, and resistance. Her work has been shown in Chicago, Detroit, Santa Fe, Ohio, Missouri, and France. She has worked with social justice and community-based organizations for over thirty years in immigrant rights, economic justice, LGBTQ issues, and domestic violence. She holds an M.F.A. in Fiber from Cranbrook Academy of Art, M.A. in Ethnic Studies from the University of California at Berkeley, and B.A. in Linguistics from Stanford University.John N. Low Ph.D. is a citizen of the Pokagon Band of Potawatomi and an associate professor at the Ohio State University, where he also serves as Director of the Newark Earthworks Center. John grew up in southwest Michigan and lived for over 15 years in Chicago. He is currently involved in projects with the Field Museum of Natural History, the City of Chicago, the Chicago History Museum, and the MacArthur Foundation.Madolyn Wesaw is Manager of Tribal Placement and Development at Four Winds Casinos, where she focuses on helping tribal citizens obtain meaningful employment and work towards their professional and educational goals. A citizen of the Pokagon Band of Potawatomi Indians, she also serves Indigenous and other marginalized groups through her work with the American Indian Movement Chapter of Indiana and Kentucky. In addition, she serves on the Interim Coordinating Committee of the Michiana Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression.Debra Yepa-Pappan (Jemez Pueblo/Korean) is a visual artist with international acclaim in the field of contemporary Native American art, a co-founder of the newly formed Chicago based Center for Native Futures, and the Native Community Engagement Coordinator at the Field Museum, where she welcomes Native American guests to the museum and facilitates their visits to collections. As an active member of the Chicago Native American community, she also serves as a liaison between the museum and the community both locally and nationally. Through her artwork and her work at the Field Museum she is committed to changing inaccurate representations of Native people, and advocates for the inclusion of Native first voice and perspectives. Yepa-Pappan lives in her hometown Chicago with her husband, artist Chris Pappan, and their daughter Ji Hae. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: The Vanishing Half
program_description: Join Woodson Regional for a discussion of The Vanishing Half by Brit Bennett. The Vignes twin sisters will always be identical. But after growing up together in a small, southern black community and running away at age sixteen, it's not just the shape of their daily lives that is different as adults, it's everything: their families, their communities, their racial identities. Ten years later, one sister lives with her black daughter in the same southern town she once tried to escape. The other secretly passes for white, and her white husband knows nothing of her past. Still, even separated by so many miles and just as many lies, the fates of the twins remain intertwined. What will happen to the next generation, when their own daughters' storylines intersect?Copies of the book are available at the Woodson Regional Library Adult Reference Desk.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Get to Work with the ICNC
program_description: Create a new resume, update an outdated resume, and discover job opportunities through the Industrial Council of Nearwest Chicago (ICNC). ICNC can refer individuals to job training providers and small business resources.In addition, the ICNC is a partner of The Hatchery Chicago. Together they offer a culinary training program for young adults. ICNC works with start-ups and established businesses in industries such as manufacturing, food/beverage, apparel/textiles and more.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. program_name: Research Your Family History with the Polish Genealogical Society of America
program_description: Curious about your ancestors? Want to map your family tree? Robert Pine, the President of the Polish Genealogical Society of America, will provide a step-by-step introduction to sleuthing out your family background starting here in the US, then how to leap the ocean to research Polish records from home. Learn how to discover who, when, what and where; and how to transform your family tree into family history. All are welcome! This workshop is geared toward folks just getting started in genealogy or anyone looking for a fun refresher.How to Attend:This event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May
program_description: Join Hall Branch for a discussion of Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. After 14 years in prison, Gerald "Stew Pot" Reeves returns home to a middle-class African-American neighborhood on Chicago's far South Side. The neighbors are nervous, even though Stew Pot has assured them that he found religion in prison and proclaims himself the moral judge of the neighborhood. Encounters and scandals with residents escalate in intensity until the community is irrevocably changed. Bedrock Faith provides a reflection on God, community, unintended consequences, and the possibilities of finding love without reservation.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Learning Circle: The Art of Storytelling with Pixar
program_description: Join a multi week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. You’ll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. This course will take place virtually, and you will need free Zoom software. Registration is required. Please register for Virtual Learning Circle The Art of Storytelling with Pixar on the P2PU website for this learning course. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4072 or email access@chipublib.org. Requests for live captioning must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Adult Reading Circle: The New Jim Crow with Dan Duster
program_description: Join the Carter G. Woodson Reading Circle as special guest Dan Duster discusses The New Jim Crow by Michelle Alexander.Dan Duster is a motivational speaker and success coach. Audiences are also inspired by the story of his great-grandmother Ida B. Wells. Duster talks about her struggles and triumphs in the late 1800s to motivate people to overcome obstacles and stand up against injustices that we see today. Born and raised on the South Side of Chicago, Duster has always been a leader.Author Michelle Alexander describes The New Jim Crow  as a stunning account of the rebirth of a caste-like system in the United States, one that has resulted in millions of African Americans locked behind bars and then relegated to a permanent second-class status—denied the very rights supposedly won in the Civil Rights Movement.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register by 3 p.m. Tuesday, October 26. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. By registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines.AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4072 or email access@chipublib.org. Requests for live captioning must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

Ivan Morgan, Consultant at Premier Benefits, will present the changes and costs for Medicare recipients. Attendees will learn about Parts A, B, C, and D and how to cover the gaps in Medicare, i.e., deductibles and coinsurance.Medicare Enrollment 2022, also known as the Medicare OEP 2022, runs between Oct. 15 and Dec. 7, 2021. Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. When visiting the library, maintain at least six feet of distance from staff and other patrons. Stay home if you or someone in your group are experiencing symptoms of any illness per order of the Chicago Department of Public Health.Questions about visiting the library? Check out our Using the Library FAQ.

program_name: Neighborhood Tour: The LGBTQ experience in Lakeview and Beyond
program_description: Over the past years, the LGBTQ experience in Chicago continues to be transformed through various activities, community groups, and individuals. As part of this program, we’ll get a chance to talk with folks at the Center on Halsted, the Legacy Walk and other community groups who continue to define and redefine the conversations around the Lakeview community and beyond. Join us for virtual neighborhood tours, featuring host and urbanologist Max Grinnell, as we explore the people, places and communities that make Chicago's neighborhoods so special! How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.AccessibilityAutomatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Feel the Fear: A Horror Roundtable Discussion
program_description: Get in the Halloween spirit and join a lively discussion with three of today's hottest voices in horror: Stephen Graham Jones, Alma Katsu, and Hailey Piper, moderated by local librarian and Horror expert Becky Spratford. They will talk about why they love Horror, how they bring the fear to life on the page, and what creators they seek out for their own frightening fun. This will be a casual and fun conversation where participation by the audience will be highly encouraged. As a special bonus, the evening will be capped off by the official kick off of the 2022 Summer Scares program with a LIVE announcement of this year's author spokesperson. For more information about Summer Scares and for librarian vetted Horror for all ages of readers please visit:  http://raforallhorror.blogspot.com/p/summer-scares.html. Come spend a spooky evening with us...if you dare!How to Attend:This event will take place on CPL's YouTube channel and Facebook page.Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.AccessibilityCaptioning is available via YouTube's captioning service. Just turn on the captioning option.

program_name: After High School: FAFSA & Financial Aid
program_description: How do you picture your life after high school? No idea? Great, because we're here to help you figure it out! After High School is a series of virtual workshops dedicated to assisting teens and their families with post-secondary decisions. So whether that means college, trade schools, jobs, or a plan uniquely designed by you, tune into one of our online sessions for reliable information and advice!This session will focus on financial aid and the process of completing the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). We will discuss what financial options are available for college, and go through the important steps for filling out the FAFSA. There will also be time given for any questions. Before working at the library, your host for this session, Marche, served as a college advisor, guiding over 200 students into their various post-secondary journeys. This included assisting with financial aid, ensuring that students and families were informed before making financial decisions for college. With experience and reliable resources, this presentation will give you tools to come to an informed decision for your finances after high school. How to Attend:This event takes place on Zoom. You'll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting approximately 24 hours before the meeting. Chicago Public Library cannot collect personal information online from kids 0 to 13. A parent or guardian’s email address must be used to register. By registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines.This event uses a third-party website and may be hosted by an organization CPL has partnered with. We recommend you review the privacy policies of any third-party sites before providing them with any personal data. For more information, please see our Website Privacy Statement. Questions about attending online events? Check out our Events FAQs.Accessibility:Automatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Do you need live captioning for this event? Are you looking to take your Excel skills to the next level? Interested in trying out the library's new partnership with LinkedIn Learning? Well then this workshop series is for you.This three week series of workshops will progress through a Microsoft Excel Learning Path titled "Excel Bootcamp." using LinkedIn Learning. Attendees can expect to learn:New ways to look up and search dataPivot TablesMacrosFilteringConditional FormattingThese workshops will assume patrons already have at least a basic understanding of Excel, so if you're brand new then consider looking for another starting point.Another main purpose of this workshop is to get attendees registered and set-up on LinkedIn Learning with their Chicago Public Library card. LinkedIn Learning is free with your card, and offers a wide variety of instructional videos on a range of industries and subjects. So if you're looking for an introduction to using this new resource consider registering to get a brief walk-though of the platform and have basic questions answered.While it is recommended to register and attend all three sessions, the programs will be designed in a way that joining part way through will be possible. Each session will focus on a different aspect of Excel's functionality, with no backtracking to previous sessions.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Have you or someone you know fallen behind on rent? Do you know your rights? Now that Illinois’ eviction moratorium has ended, landlords will soon be able to begin eviction proceedings but it’s not too late to apply for rental assistance. Learn how you can apply for rental assistance, legally resist evictions, and understand how the court eviction system works.Working Family Solidarity Executive Director Leone Jose Bicchieri will facilitate a free panel presentation with representatives from the State of Illinois, the City of Chicago, and the Lawyers Committee for Better Housing to connect people to the information and resources available to help people stay in their homes.  There will be time for questions and comments. Spanish/English interpretation is available.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register by Tues., October 26 . program_name: Goodnight Mr. Vincent Van Gogh - Screening With Filmmaker Q & A
program_description: How do we talk to children about suicide? Please join us for a virtual screening of a short animation offering a gentle way."Goodnight Mr. Vincent Van Gogh" was created to help support those who have lost someone to suicide and to promote forward thinking on suicide awareness. The animation is based on the children’s book, “Goodnight Mr. Vincent Van Gogh,” which is on permanent display in the Vincent Van Gogh Library in Nuenen, Netherlands.Both the book and the film were created by suicide loss survivor Lindsey Doolittle, who will join us via Zoom for the screening and a post-film Q & A. How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Advanced Care Planning with Five Wishes
program_description: One of the greatest gifts you can give your family is to provide guidance on the treatments you would – and would not – want to receive if you were unable to speak for yourself. This is called advance care planning. Sharing this information with your family and loved ones will provide them with peace of mind, while also assuring that your wishes will be honored.Five Wishes is an easy-to-use legal document that is valid in Illinois and most other states, and is written in everyday language that lets adults plan how they want to be cared for in case they become seriously ill. Five Wishes speaks to a person’s holistic needs: medical, personal, emotional and spiritual.Presented by Maureen Burns, Community Health Worker, JourneyCare.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Rick Kessler, Research Professor at Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics (KICP) at the University of Chicago, will discuss the motivation for the Dark Energy Survey (DES), the survey instrument and 6-years of data taking (2013-2018), and some of its results.The Dark Energy Survey is an international, collaborative effort to map hundreds of millions of galaxies, detect thousands of supernovae, and find patterns of cosmic structure that will reveal the nature of the mysterious dark energy that is accelerating the expansion of our Universe. DES began searching the Southern skies on August 31, 2013.According to Einstein’s theory of General Relativity, gravity should lead to a slowing of the cosmic expansion. Yet, in 1998, two teams of astronomers studying distant supernovae made the remarkable discovery that the expansion of the universe is speeding up. To explain cosmic acceleration, cosmologists are faced with two possibilities: either 70% of the universe exists in an exotic form, now called dark energy, that exhibits a gravitational force opposite to the attractive gravity of ordinary matter, or General Relativity must be replaced by a new theory of gravity on cosmic scales.DES is designed to probe the origin of the accelerating universe and help uncover the nature of dark energy by measuring the 14-billion-year history of cosmic expansion with high precision. More than 400 scientists from over 25 institutions in the United States, Spain, the United Kingdom, Brazil, Germany, Switzerland, and Australia are working on the project. The collaboration built is using an extremely sensitive 570-Megapixel digital camera, DECam, mounted on the Blanco 4-meter telescope at Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory, high in the Chilean Andes, to carry out the project.Over six years (2013-2019), the DES collaboration used 758 nights of observation to carry out a deep, wide-area survey to record information from 300 million galaxies that are billions of light-years from Earth. The survey imaged 5000 square degrees of the southern sky in five optical filters to obtain detailed information about each galaxy. A fraction of the survey time is used to observe smaller patches of sky roughly once a week to discover and study thousands of supernovae and other astrophysical transients.The talk will last approximately 45 minutes – 1 hour.Registration via email is required. See the link above or phone 312-747-4400 or visit chipublib.org for more information.  How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Join Independence Branch for an online discussion of feminist fiction and non-fiction!Our second title to be discussed will be Roxane Gay's Bad Feminist.  "This trenchant collection assembles previously published essays and new work by cultural critic and novelist Gay (An Untamed State). Even though she loves pink, feels nostalgic about the Sweet Valley High series, and lets degrading rap lyrics blast from her car stereo, Gay is passionately committed to feminist issues, such as equal opportunity and pay and reproductive freedom. Writing about race, politics, gender, feminism, privilege, and popular media, she highlights how deeply misogyny is embedded in our culture, the careless language used to discuss sexual violence (seen in news reports of sexual assault), Hollywood's tokenistic treatment of race, the trivialization of literature written by women, and the many ways American society fails women and African-Americans. Gay bemoans that fact that role models like Bill Cosby and Don Lemon urge African-Americans to act like ideal citizens while glossing over institutional problems in the education, social welfare, and justice system that exacerbate racism and poverty. Although Gay is aware of her privilege as a middle-class Haitian-American, she doesn't refrain from advising inner-city students to have higher expectations. Whatever her topic, Gay's provocative essays stand out for their bravery, wit, and emotional honesty." ---Publisher's WeeklyHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Chicago Literary Hall of Fame presents the Fuller Award to Luis Alberto Urrea
program_description: Chicago Public Library is pleased to continue its long collaboration with Chicago Literary Hall of Fame in presentation of the Fuller Award for Lifetime Achievement to Luis Alberto Urrea.Luis Alberto Urrea will become the 11th Chicago author to receive the Chicago Literary Hall of Fame's prestigious Fuller Award for Lifetime Achievement as an author, teacher, and activist. The event is free and open to the public, with live attendance at the National Museum of Mexican Art and livestream via Zoom. Sara Paretsky, Daniel Borzutzky and Dave Eggers will offer tributes; actress Laura Crotte will perform a dramatic reading; and Coya Paz will lead a conversation with Luis. A 2005 Pulitzer Prize finalist for nonfiction and member of the LatinoLiterature Hall of Fame, Urrea is the critically acclaimed and best-selling author of17 books, winning numerous awards for his poetry, fiction and essays. Born inTijuana to a Mexican father and American mother, Urrea is most recognized as aborder writer, though he says, “I am more interested in bridges, not borders.”Partners for the event include National Museum of Mexican Art, American WritersMuseum, Poetry Foundation, University of Illinois Chicago, The Tuesday Agency,Chicago Public Library, Columbia College Chicago, The Book Group, Third World Press, The Bookstore of Glen Ellyn and Guild Literary Complex.Registration is required. This event is free and open to the public, either in-person or virtually. Registration is available here: FULLER AWARD CEREMONY.

program_name: Nostalgia Book Club: Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark
program_description: When was the last time you revisited one of your favorite books from childhood? This month we will be discussing a scary read - Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark by Alvin Schwartz.  Are the stories as creepy as we remember?  Read the book on your own and let's get together to talk about it.Stories of ghosts and witches, "jump" stories, scary songs, and modern-day scary stories. Schwartz is best known for the Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark series, which featured gruesome, nightmarish illustrations by Stephen Gammell. The series was America's most frequently challenged book (or book series) for library inclusion of 1990-1999.  --Publisher's description.You can check out Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark at your favorite Chicago Public Library branch by placing a hold request.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Join the West Loop Branch for a discussion of Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May After fourteen years in prison, Gerald "Stew Pot" Reeves, age thirty-one, returns home to live with his mom in Parkland, a black middle-class neighborhood on Chicago's South Side. A frightening delinquent before being sent away, his return sends Parkland residents into a religiously infused tailspin, which only increases when Stew Pot announces that he experienced a religious awakening in prison. Through the unforgettable characters of Stew Pot and Mrs. Motley, the novel provides a reflection on God, the living and the dead, and the possibilities of finding love without reservation.A limited number of copies are located behind the circulation desk at the West Loop Branch.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Just As I Am by Cicely Tyson
program_description: Join Pullman Branch Library for a discussion of Cicely Tyson's memoir, Just as I Am."Just As I Am is my truth. It is me, plain and unvarnished, with the glitter and garland set aside. In these pages, I am indeed Cicely, the actress who has been blessed to grace the stage and screen for six decades. Yet I am also the church girl who once rarely spoke a word. I am the teenager who sought solace in the verses of the old hymn for which this book is named. I am a daughter and mother, a sister, and a friend. I am an observer of human nature and the dreamer of audacious dreams. I am a woman who has hurt as immeasurably as I have loved, a child of God divinely guided by His hand. And here in my ninth decade, I am a woman who, at long last, has something meaningful to say."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Paint Your Story: Your Voice on Canvas
program_description: Polish artist Patricia Stepniak uses mixed media and Polish folk tales to inspire kids to create their own picture stories using watercolors, oil pastels, ink and scrapbooking materials. All supplies provided!A graduate of the Fine Arts School in Poland, Patricia Stepniak’s whole life is centered around sharing her artistic talents with the world. Patricia is well versed in many different areas of the fine arts, including painting, designing and sculpting among others. She teaches, creates art and uses her knowledge to train the next generation of artists at her own studio – PatriciaARTStudio.This event is sponsored by the Polish American Services Committee in celebration of Polish American Heritage Month.How to AttendThis event takes place in person. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Mapping the Interior
program_description: All are welcome to join a book discussion of Mapping the Interior by Stephen Graham Jones.“Blackfeet author Stephen Graham Jones brings readers a spine-tingling Native American horror novella. Walking through his own house at night, a fifteen-year-old thinks he sees another person stepping through a doorway. Instead of the people who could be there, his mother or his brother, the figure reminds him of his long-gone father, who died mysteriously before his family left the reservation. When he follows it, he discovers his house is bigger and deeper than he knew. The house is the kind of wrong place where you can lose yourself and find things you'd rather not have. Over the course of a few nights, the boy tries to map out his house in an effort that puts his little brother in the worst danger, and puts him in the position to save them . . . at terrible cost.” - from the publisher, Tor.comHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register until 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting before the event. program_name: Hospice 101: Understanding Hospice Care & Its Benefits
program_description: Hospice care is one of the most unique and robust types of care covered under Medicare. However, many people don’t know much about this type of care. This workshop will describe in detail what hospice is, who is eligible, who pays for care, and what services are included. We will also discuss common misconceptions about hospice care and how lived experiences influence people’s care decisions. Learn all that hospice has to offer and how it can look different for each individual. Presented by Maureen Burns, Rogers Park Area Community Health Worker at JourneyCare.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Please register by 11 a.m. Friday, October 29. You'll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. Angela Seals is an award-nominee indie author and Chicago native with an awesome imagination for storytelling. She currently works as a senior accountant by day and a writer by night. Her novels offer real life issues and compelling love affairs and speak to her readers desire to find love by providing life, imagery, and words to their thoughts and fantasies. These dynamic stories derived from her love of reading, which began in her early teens. Angela pens contemporary romance and women fiction. However, out of her love for all genres grew her alter-ego Angel de’Amor. Manifested from the edgy characters floating around in her head that could not be contained, Angel de’Amar was born to dominate her love for her fiery women fiction stories. Angela continues to write under both names to offer her readers a variety of stories filled with temptation and forbidden love affairs. Angela loves connecting with her readers and you can find her curled up reading a book or working on her next dynamic, sultry story. Additionally, Angela will discuss her current release The Royal Mess (Modern Day Socialite Book One) and future projects with the readers. Copies of this title will be available at Walker Branch  Hopelessly ForeverHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. This month, we're reading Mexican Gothic by Silvia Moreno-Garcia.After receiving a frantic letter from her newly-wed cousin begging for someone to save her from a mysterious doom, Noemí Taboada heads to High Place, a distant house in the Mexican countryside. She’s not sure what she will find—her cousin’s husband, a handsome Englishman, is a stranger, and Noemí knows little about the region.Noemí is also an unlikely rescuer: She’s a glamorous debutante, and her chic gowns and perfect red lipstick are more suited for cocktail parties than amateur sleuthing. But she’s also tough and smart, with an indomitable will, and she is not afraid: Not of her cousin’s new husband, who is both menacing and alluring; not of his father, the ancient patriarch who seems to be fascinated by Noemí; and not even of the house itself, which begins to invade Noemí’s dreams with visions of blood and doom. (Goodreads, 2021). How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. program_name: Monday Matinee: Once Upon a Time in Hollywood (2019)
program_description: In 1960s Los Angeles, silver screen actor Rick Dalton and his stunt double turned best friend, Cliff Booth, struggle to keep pace with the swiftly evolving entertainment industry. They both work to continue their notoriety while facing the demise of Hollywood's Golden Age. ©Columbia Pictures Industries Inc., 161 minutes, Rated RCommunity Cinema is at a branch near you!  Check out hundreds of other screenings at libraries across Chicago.

program_name: The Neighborhood Notebook with I Am Adverb
program_description: The Neighborhood Notebook provides fun and engaging writing activities that build community and develop writing skills. Over the course of the workshops, you will read a prompt, submit an entry/response, and share their writing, developing a Neighborhood Notebook of poems and culminating in a reading. I Am Adverb is a board member of Abj Millennial Tribe, a spoken word artist, program instructor and team lead of Original Men In Black. This is being presented as a three part series, and you should plan to attend all three workshops. This event is co-sponsored by CPL’s Poetry Committee.How to Attend:These workshops will be presented virtually online. program_name: DACA 101: Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals
program_description: Chicago Law and Education Foundation is pleased to present DACA 101. Learn more about the program, what it does and doesn't do in this informational seminar. Discussion will include DACA's history and where it stands right now, and detail some of the impact the program has already had. Will discuss eligibility to apply for DACA, what the requirements are, and what applicants need to prove they meet them. We'll talk about where to obtain documents and evidence and run through some hypothetical scenarios. Finally, we'll answer any questions and let attendees know how they can contact us to start the application process. How to Attend:This event takes place on Zoom. Please register by 12 p.m. the day of the event. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Learning Circle: The Art of Storytelling with Pixar
program_description: Join a multi week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. You’ll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. This course will take place virtually, and you will need free Zoom software. Registration is required. Please register for Virtual Learning Circle The Art of Storytelling with Pixar on the P2PU website for this learning course. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. program_name: The Ribbon Skirts of Agnes Woodward
program_description: Agnes WoodwardJoin us for a talk about Native/Indigenous ribbon skirts and sisterhood with Agnes Woodward. AgnesWoodward is Plains Cree from Kawacatoose First Nations, Saskatchewan, Canada. Shehas lived in North Dakota with her husband and children for the last sixteen years.Agnesis an MMIWG2S family member and advocate, an activist, Speaker, grassroots community organizer, and co-owner of ReeCreeations. Agnesis a proud ribbon skirt maker who uses applique art as a way to tell stories, empower Indigenous people, bring healing, visibility and connection to Indigenous identity.How to AttendThis event will take place on CPL's YouTube channel and Facebook channels. Can't make it to the live stream? We will archive the video to watch later.AccessibilityCaptioning can be turned on by the user on both YouTube and Facebook.

Join the South Shore Book Club for a discussion of Disappearing Earth by Julia Phillips.One August afternoon, two sisters--Sophia, eight, and Alyona, eleven--go missing from a beach on the Kamchatka Peninsula in northeastern Russia.  Taking us through the year that follows, Disappearing Earth enters the lives of the women and girls in this tightly knit community who are connected by the crime:  a witness, a neighbor, a detective, a mother.Copies available for checkout at South Shore Branch's Circulation Desk.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. program_name: Neighborhood Tour: The Communion Around Beverages
program_description: In Bedrock Faith, people gather. Some people gather around martinis. Other people gather around beer. And still others gather around other beverages. This guided tour through Chicago will talk about why Windy City residents of legal age gather around in lounges, taverns, and other places for cold libations and conversation with others. It will be a spirited conversation. Join us for virtual neighborhood tours, featuring host and urbanologist Max Grinnell, as we explore the people, places and communities that make Chicago's neighborhoods so special! How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.AccessibilityAutomatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Rapbrary Book Discussion: Decoded by Jay Z
program_description: Join CPL and the Richard M. Daley Branch as we read and discuss Decoded by Jay Z and enjoy renditions of his greatest hits from violinist Edith Yokley of the Chicago Sinfonietta's Resident Orchestra Project. We commemorate the 18th anniversary of Jay Z's the Black Album, and the 10 year anniversary of Decoded by Jay Z; a compelling work, that makes the case that Hip Hop lyrics are poetry. "Decoded is the autobiography and memoir of rapper Jay-Z, published by Random House and released November 16, 2010 on hardcover and November 1, 2011 on paperback. The book combines lyrics, their explanations, anecdotes, reflections, and autobiographical information. Jay-Z explains the three reasons why he wanted to write the book being a case for hip-hop lyrics as poetry, to tell a generational story turned into powerful experiences and revolved as a story everyone can relate to."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: David Sadowski on Chicago’s Lost Ls
program_description: Chicago’s system of elevated railways, known locally as the “L,” has run continuously since 1892 and, like the city, has never stood still. It helped neighborhoods grow, brought their increasingly diverse populations together, and gave the famous Loop its name. But today’s system has changed radically over the years. Chicago's Lost "L"s tells the story of former lines such as Garfield Park, Humboldt Park, Kenwood, Stockyards, Normal Park, Westchester, and Niles Center. It was once possible to take high-speed trains on the L directly to Aurora, Elgin, and Milwaukee, Wisconsin. The L started out as four different companies, two starting out using steam engines instead of electricity. Eventually, all four came together via the Union Loop. The L is more than a way of getting around. Its trains are a place where people meet and interact. Some say the best way to experience the city is via the L, with its second-story view. Chicago’s Lost “L”s is virtually a “secret history” of Chicago, and this is your ticket.Author David Sadowski grew up riding the L all over the city. He is the author of Chicago Trolleys and Building Chicago's Subways and runs the online Trolley Dodger blog.How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. You'll be able to ask questions during the event as well! Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.AccessibilityAutomatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Kartemquin Films Presents 2021 Empowering Truth Benefit
program_description: Chicago Public Library and Kartemquin Films have collaborated on several exciting projects over the past years. Kartemquin Films is thrilled to be hosting their third annual Empowering Truth Benefit celebrating the 55-year legacy of Kartemquin Films as Chicago’s documentary powerhouse. They have put together an amazing virtual line up to celebrate their past, present and future as a leading advocate for independent nonfiction media. Celebrating the voices and work of KTQ filmmakers and drawing on their rich history, the Empowering Truth Benefit will engage themes of equity and representation in the media field through a series of dynamic conversations. To learn more about this event and to register, please visit Kartemquin's Empowering Truth Benefit. We encourage you to attend this free virtual event!

program_name: Feng Shui: Take Command of your Life
program_description: When you put yourself in "Command" of your life, your life improves, situations shift, and many new opportunities may show up in unexpected ways. Learn how to position yourself for the best possibilities to come your way using the time tested guidelines of Feng Shui.  Laurie Pawli will share information on exactly how to incorporate these methods into your space for your benefit.Laurie is a student of Grand Master Professor Lin Yun with her Feng Shui Certification from The Integrative School of Feng Shui in San Diego, CA. program_name: 1993, Another Summer, Sound of Chicago’s Funky Drummer
program_description: What was Chicago like in 1993? Utilizing Chicago Tribune articles, author and urbanologist Max Grinnell looks into news stories about Cabrini Green, the new Comiskey Park, public schools, and other matters to talk about the cultural and social milieu around the city. Along the way, we'll also check in at the Chicago Bulls 1993 championship rally, listen to some local radio legends Eddie & JoBo, and hear about Moo & Oink's meat products.As an urbanologist, geographer, historian, and professor, Max Grinnell finds his purpose in describing, critiquing, and analyzing the urban condition. He’s an expert on urban design, planning, public art, the creative economy, and the history of cities, and has written several books including Hyde Park, Illinois and 24 Great Walks in Chicago. How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.AccessibilityAutomatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: The Feather Thief
program_description: Join us as we discuss The Feather Thief by Kirk Wallace Johnson. The Feather Thief recounts the enthralling story of a young, gifted musician who robbed the British Museum at Tring of more than a million dollars' worth of rare bird specimens for their beautiful feathers, coveted by fly tiers like himself. In the late 18th and 19th centuries, there was considerable demand for bird feathers, particularly from exotic birds, for fashion. The feathers are also in demand among fly tiers, which is how Rist, a young American studying music at the Royal Academy of Music and one of the best fly tiers in the world, was compelled to rob the museum. Johnson chases down priceless specimens that were sold by Rist and interviews Rist himself to dive deeper into the obsessive and strange world of fly tiers.Copies of this month's selection will be available 30 days prior to the event at the 6th floor reference desk at Harold Washington Library Center (400 South State Street, Chicago IL, 60605).How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register by 12 p.m. on Thursday, November 4. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Know Your Rights with Cabrini Green Legal Aid
program_description: Have you ever wondered - What exactly is a criminal record? Whether you have to say “yes” if an employer asks if you have ever been arrested? What is the difference between sealing and expungement? If you are eligible to expunge or seal your record? Cabrini Green Legal Aid representatives will present a workshop to answer all these questions and more. How to Attend:These workshops will be presented virtually online. You will need to download free Zoom software. Advance registration is required. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Just in time for Fall, start a tactile indoor hobby and try out hand stitching. Learn the materials, tools, and methods of hand embroidery as well as a variety of beginning embroidery stitches. With instructor guidance, you will utilize these new skills to begin a floral sampler. All supplies provided. For ages 12 and up.Millicent Kennedy is a Chicago based artist, and bookbinder who received her MFA from Northern Illinois University. She teaches bookbinding, printmaking and embroidery classes at Evanston Art Center, Lillstreet Art Center, and co-curates at Parlour and Ramp Gallery in the Pilsen Neighborhood of Chicago. Registration is required and space is limited.How to AttendThis event takes place in person. Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. program_description: The Neighborhood Notebook provides fun and engaging writing activities that build community and develop writing skills. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: The Lake on Fire
program_description: Join the Clearing Branch for a discussion of The Lake on Fire. Copies of the book are available at the front circulation desk.The Lake on Fire is an epic narrative that begins among 19th century Jewish immigrants on a failing Wisconsin farm. Dazzled by lore of the American dream, Chaya and her strange, brilliant, young brother Asher stow away to Chicago; what they discover there, however, is a Gilded Age as empty a façade as the beautiful Columbian Exposition luring thousands to Lake Michigan’s shore. The pair scrapes together a meager living―Chaya in a cigar factory; Asher, roaming the city and stealing books and jewelry to share with the poor, until they find different paths of escape. An examination of family, love, and revolution, this profound tale resonates eerily with today’s current events and tumultuous social landscape. The Lake on Fire is robust, gleaming, and grimy all at once, proving that celebrated author Rosellen Brown is back with a story as luminous as ever.How to Attend:This event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. By registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines.  This event uses a third-party website and may be hosted by an organization CPL has partnered with. We recommend you review the privacy policies of any third-party sites before providing them with any personal data. For more information, please see our Website Privacy Statement.Questions about attending online events? Check out our Events FAQs. An archivist from CPL’s Northside Neighborhood History Collection shares images of Chicago’s Uptown neighborhood in the 1980s and 1990s from the Robert W. Krueger Photograph Collection. Included are images of some of Uptown’s more well-known landmarks as well as less famous locations that played important roles in the daily lives of community members.  Tune in for a special series of videos featuring archival material related to Chicago’s neighborhoods. CPL archivists and librarians showcase secrets and treasures from the archives that highlight our city’s history.  How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.AccessibilityAutomatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Hospice 101: Understanding Hospice Care and its Benefits
program_description: Hospice care is one of the most unique and robust types of care covered under Medicare. However, many people don’t know much about this type of care. This workshop will describe in detail, what hospice is, who is eligible, who pays for care, and what services are included. We will also discuss common misconceptions about hospice care and how lived experiences influence people’s care decisions. Learn all that hospice has to offer and how it can look different for each individual. This event is presented by Maureen Burns, Rogers Park Area Community Health Worker at JourneyCare.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 1 day before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Obtención de su Tarjeta Verde: Sesión de Información sobre el Ajuste del Estado
program_description: La Biblioteca Pública de Harold Washington está organizando una presentación virtual en PowerPoint sobre "How to Get Your Green Card” (cómo obtener su residencia legal permanente). María del Carmen Rodríguez, Oficial de Relaciones comunitarias del USCIS, realizará una visión general del proceso de adaptación a la residencia legal permanente (LPR). Oficial Rodríguez discutirá las categorías de visa, el proceso de entrada en los Estados Unidos, y los requisitos de elegibilidad para aquellos que buscan el estatus LPR. La discusión incluirá una descripción de los muchos tipos de visas disponibles—tanto no inmigrantes como inmigrantes, y los tipos de ajustes de LPR—basados en la familia y el empleo. Al final de la presentación habrá una oportunidad para hacer preguntas.Cómo asistir:Este evento tiene lugar en Zoom. Regístrese antes de las 10 a.m. del día anterior al evento. Recibirá un correo electrónico con un enlace a la reunión segura de Zoom aproximadamente 24 horas antes de la reunión. Al registrarse para este evento, acepta cumplir con las Pautas de uso de la biblioteca.AccesibilidadAccesibilidad de transcripción automático está incluido en todos los eventos de CPL usando Zoom.  Necesita subtitulado en vivo para el evento. Por favor llame al (312) 747-4072 o mande un correo electrónico a: access@chicago.org.  Las solicitudes para subtitulados en vivo se deben hacer por lo menos 14 días laborales antes del evento.DACA protects young people, who came to the United States as children, from deportation, and provides for work authorization, advance parole and better life opportunities. Presenters will address the history & current status of DACA, as well as eligibility for initial & renewal applications. The presentation will be followed by Q&A.Please note, this event will take place in Spanish.

program_name: Learning Circle: The Art of Storytelling with Pixar
program_description: Join a multi week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. You’ll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. This course will take place virtually, and you will need free Zoom software. Registration is required. Please register for Virtual Learning Circle The Art of Storytelling with Pixar on the P2PU website for this learning course. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. program_name: Walking in Two Worlds: Growing up Indigenous in Turtle Island
program_description: Madolyn WesawActivist Madolyn Wesaw discusses the complexities of growing up Indigenous in modern America. From erasure in educational systems to misrepresentation in pop culture, learn what we can do to create a more inclusive future for native youth.Madolyn Wesaw is an indigenous activist and mother. A citizen of the Pokagon Band of Potawatomi Indians, she serves Indigenous and other marginalized groups through her work with the American Indian Movement Chapter of Indiana and Kentucky. In addition, Madolyn serves on the Interim Coordinating Committee of the Michiana Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression. She has been involved in projects with the Civil Rights Heritage Center in South Bend, IN., The Kroc Institute for International Peace Studies, and the Newberry Library.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Please register at least 24 hours before the event begins. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Wounded by Ben Burgess Jr.
program_description: Join Brainerd Branch Urban Book Club for a discussion of Wounded by Ben Burgess Jr."Samantha Miller didn't have an easy start. Molested as a child and subsequently forced into prostitution by her drug-addicted mother, Samantha learned at an early age that men were not to be trusted. Being constantly preyed upon taught her to be a predator. Her target was women straight or married. As the headliner at a local strip club, Samantha capitalizes on the gifts she was cursed with. In turn, her life quickly spirals down a dangerous path of violence, seduction, and exploitation. When Sasha is brought on as the new bartender, she becomes Samantha's newest target. The last thing Samantha anticipated was falling in love. When tragedy strikes, what was once a challenge may prove to be her downfall. Can Samantha heal from her abusive past, or will she always be Wounded"How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. program_name: Neighborhood Tour: A Diverse Business Landscape, Chicago Style
program_description: What makes a great neighborhood? What makes a great retail environment? Most people would probably say that they would like to patronize a diverse set of businesses as they make their way around Chicago. On this tour, we’ll hear from some different business owners about their own challenges and opportunities, along with talking a bit about the history of these businesses. Join us for virtual neighborhood tours, featuring host and urbanologist Max Grinnell, as we explore the people, places and communities that make Chicago's neighborhoods so special! How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.AccessibilityAutomatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org
