program_name: Historic Chicago Parks: A Research Workshop
program_description: Parks and open spaces have played a vital role in Chicago life for centuries. The Chicago Public Library is the repository for an enormous collection of archival plans, drawings, photographs, and documents that can help illuminate the history of these fascinating public spaces. Join Julia Bachrach and Johanna Russ, curators of the exhibit From Swamps to Parks: Building Chicago’s Public Spaces, for a hands-on virtual workshop that will show you how to access and utilize materials from the collections of the Chicago Public Library to illuminate the history of Chicago’s parks and open spaces. Learn more about park history in the exhibit From Swamps to Parks: Building Chicago's Public Spaces, on display now at Harold Washington Library Center in the 9th floor Exhibit Hall.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Rapbrary Book Discussion: Decoded by Jay Z
program_description: Join CPL and the Richard M. Daley Branch as we read and discuss Decoded by Jay Z and enjoy renditions of his greatest hits from violinist Edith Yokley of the Chicago Sinfonietta's Resident Orchestra Project. We commemorate the 18th anniversary of Jay Z's the Black Album, and the 10 year anniversary of Decoded by Jay Z; a compelling work, that makes the case that Hip Hop lyrics are poetry. "Decoded is the autobiography and memoir of rapper Jay-Z, published by Random House and released November 16, 2010 on hardcover and November 1, 2011 on paperback. The book combines lyrics, their explanations, anecdotes, reflections, and autobiographical information. Jay-Z explains the three reasons why he wanted to write the book being a case for hip-hop lyrics as poetry, to tell a generational story turned into powerful experiences and revolved as a story everyone can relate to."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Make and Care Drop-In Studio with ArtWorks
program_description: Join us the first three Wednesdays of every month to engage in self and collective care through arts and crafts making. This is an opportunity to commit time to your art/craft practice, meet new people, and support one another for the sake of mutual care and wellbeing.At the virtual drop-in studio, you can use any arts or crafts materials you have on hand to make whatever you’d like, though there will be a weekly theme at the ready if you need some inspiration. program_name: Betty Crocker and Her Cookbook That Changed How America Cooks with Leslie Goddard
program_description: Long before Martha Stewart, there was Betty Crocker. In 1950, her brand-new picture cookbook hit the shelves. To date, it has sold more than 75 million copies. Created in 1921 by a flour company, Betty Crocker became the most famous and most trusted advisor to American cooks. This fun illustrated lecture by historian Leslie Goddard, Ph.D. and hosted by Edgebrook Branch, looks at how Betty Crocker was invented, why her cookbook has endured and what makes her so iconic. It’s perfect if you’re feeling like cooking up some nostalgia.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom, and registration is required to attend. You'll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. By registering for this event you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines.This event uses a third-party website and may be hosted by an organization CPL has partnered with. Johnnie JaeTune in for an interview with multimedia organizer Johnnie Jae and learn more about how Native/Indigenous creators are breaking through and creating their own multimedia platforms to tell their stories. Johnnie Jae is an Otoe-Missouria and Choctaw rabble-rousing journalist, organizer, creator, and futurist who loves empowering others to chase their passions and create for healing and revolutionary change in the world. She is the founder of A Tribe Called Geek, an award-winning media platform for Indigenous Geek Culture and STEM, and #Indigenerds4Hope, a suicide prevention initiative designed to educate, encourage, and empower Native youth. Jae is a co-founder of Not Your Mascots and LiveIndigenousOK. She is a member of the Women Warriors Work Collective and served as a co-chair for the March for Racial Justice. She leads numerous workshops that address Mental Health and Suicide in Indian Country, Native Mascots & Stereotypes, Indigenous Representation & Journalism, Indigenous STEM & Tech, and the Utilization of Social & Digital media for Business and Activism. Her ability to seamlessly shift from humor and pop culture to advocacy and business has made her a much-sought after speaker, panelist, and commentator.How to AttendThis event will take place on CPL's YouTube channel and Facebook channels. Can't make it to the live stream? We will archive the video to watch later.AccessibilityCaptioning can be turned on by the user on both YouTube and Facebook.

program_name: Art of Asemic Drawing with Kaye Buchman
program_description: Students in this workshop will explore the art of asemic drawing, a creative form of expressive mark making derived from handwriting, cursive writing, and calligraphy.  Using commercial ink pens and color pencils, we will experiment with a variety of asemic drawing methods including angular, looping, and freeform styles.  Afterwards, we will add color to create patterns and subjects of interest.  The workshop is open to students of all levels and no prior drawing experience required.  Drawing materials will be provided.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. program_name: Diamonds in the Rough: the Legacy of Nisei Baseball
program_description: Join us for a quick peek into the world of Issei American Baseball and the life of pioneering baseball players Kenichi Zenimura and Wally Yonamine.  The first part of the program screens a 34 minute documentary about Zenimura which focuses his time in the Gila River (AZ) concentration camp where he built a baseball field of dreams (On a Pima Indian Reservation).  The movie also covers the post-WWII era when Nisei players returned to Japan to become major stars of the Japanese Professional leagues. These ‘Bridge Builders’ and American Ambassadors of baseball are the ‘Godfathers’ to today’s all-stars in MLB like Shohei Ohtani, Ichiro, Nomo, Matsui, Murakami, etc. Interviews with Zenimura's widow, and Yonamine are included.  Actor "Pat" Morita is the co-writer and narrator.  Following the screening, Kerry Yo Nakagawa (DIrector/Producer) will give a short talk and respond to questions from the audience. Please join us for a look at a very different aspect of baseball history. Diamonds in the Rough, a product of the Nisei Baseball Research Project (NBRP) (www.niseibaseball.com) was made by Chip Taylor Communications.  This year the NBRP celebrates its 25th Anniversary.  We are pleased to bring you this program in recognition of the work this organization conducts.This program is made possible through the joint efforts of the Asian American/Pacific Islander Cultural Committee and the Social Sciences and History Department of the Chicago Public Library.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Is that Love in the Air? Short Films with ReelAbilities Chicago
program_description: Reel Abilities Chicago Logo Join us to view online four short films followed by a live conversation shedding new light on dating and relationships with ReelAbilities Chicago. Single (14min.) Kim, who was born with one arm, gets set up on a blind date. When she finally meets Jake, she quickly realizes he also has a physical disability, and she is pissed. An unapologetic perspective on the complexities of being disabled and dating.Second Time (4 min.) A deaf couple chats at a party while everyone else observes the beginning of a beautiful love story. But is the conversation as innocent as it seems?Boldly Go (6 min.) A young gay man is hiding a secret. When a long-term crush tries to seduce him at a party, he is forced to expose the truth.Full Picture (11min.) Santina has been in a wheelchair since she was six years old. With meetings, hangouts, and classes happening virtually due to the coronavirus quarantine, she's experiencing something new—choosing when (or if) to disclose her disability.Accessibility: All films will be screened with open captions and audio description. Discussion, questions and answers will have ASL and live captioning.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Join the Austin Branch's Soulful Perspectives book club for a discussion of Passing by Nella Larsen.Married to a successful physician and prominently ensconced in Harlem's vibrant society of the 1920s, Irene Redfield leads a charmed existence-until she is shaken out of it by a chance encounter with a childhood friend who has been "passing for white." An important figure in the Harlem Renaissance, Nella Larsen was the first African-American woman to be awarded a Guggenheim fellowship. Her fictional portraits of women seeking their identities through a fog of racial confusion were informed by her own Danish-West Indian parentage, and Passing offers fascinating psychological insights into issues of race and gender.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_description: Join children's librarian Miss Pam of the North Pulaski branch for an introduction to the branch's Vox and Wonder Books collection.  This is a collection of books that have a built-in audio device which makes listening to the book easy and convenient.  Who can benefit from using these books?  new and emerging readersESL learners of all ageskids who want some independenceparents who need a breakfamilies trying to find alternatives to screensThese books are available for check out.  If you wish to use them in the library, please bring a pair of headphones or earbuds. "This is the Zodiac speaking..."Join the Vodak-East Side Branch for a virtual discussion on the Zodiac killer; who possibly murdered 37 people, was particular to codes and ciphers to go with his crimes, and taunted Bay Area newspapers with threats in the late 1960's. Below is a list of possible resources to learn about the Zodiac but feel free to use your own, no reading required! We’ll talk about this unusual and unsolved case that still causes widespread speculation and delve into Zodiac's obsessive need to be publicized.  Discover further resources for exploration on the Zodiac killer:Book - "This Is the Zodiac Speaking"Podcast - Monster: The Zodiac KillerYouTube Documentary - Zodiac Killer Documentary Series - The Most Dangerous Animal of AllRecent Developments :Zodiac Cipher Solved 51 Years After It Was Sent to NewspaperIndependent Group Claims It Solved the MysteryHow To Attend:This event takes place on Zoom. Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. program_name: The Neighborhood Notebook with I Am Adverb
program_description: The Neighborhood Notebook provides fun and engaging writing activities that build community and develop writing skills. Over the course of the workshops, you will read a prompt, submit an entry/response, and share their writing, developing a Neighborhood Notebook of poems and culminating in a reading. I Am Adverb is a board member of Abj Millennial Tribe, a spoken word artist, program instructor and team lead of Original Men In Black. This is being presented as a three part series, and you should plan to attend all three workshops. This event is co-sponsored by CPL’s Poetry Committee.How to Attend:These workshops will be presented virtually online. program_description: Please join Legler Regional staff as we discuss A Little Bit of Karma by ReShonda Tate Billingsley."Meet Shannon and Jay Lovejoy-the rich and successful power couple who, to the fans of their call-in radio show, seem like they've got it all. program_name: Urban Book Discussion: Dirty Little Secrets
program_description: Please join Legler Regional staff as we discuss Dirty Little Secrets By Joy King."Nothing prepares Tyler Blake for the fast-paced living of New York City. A small-town girl from Georgia, she quickly gets caught up in the glamorous entertainment industry. While pursuing her dream of becoming an actress, Tyler continually gets sidetracked by men who promise to help her and finds herself going from one dysfunctional relationship to another. Just when Tyler finally believes she has found her ideal man, in hip-hop producer Brian McCall, everything begins to go horribly wrong. Trapped in a nightmarish relationship, Tyler is determined not to go down without a fight."The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. program_name: The Quiet Year – Community Storytelling and Mapmaking Game
program_description: Using gameplay as a means of building community, join the library as we explore and play the critically acclaimed storytelling and cartography game The Quiet Year by designer Avery Alder.  The Quiet Year is a unique game built around map making and community life after a devastating event. Players will use a deck of cards that correspond to weeks of the year, with each card representing one week.  Each week brings questions and decisions driven by luck, omens, and other elements that affect everyone and everything in the fictional community being built.  Each of these elements are then added to a map which takes shape over the course of the year.  By the end of the game, players will have collaboratively told the story one year of community life and represented it on a shared map.  No need for roleplaying game experience to join, though this program is aimed towards teen and adult audiences.How to Attend:This game will take place virtually. You will need to download free Zoom software. Advance registration is required. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4072 or email access@chipublib.org. Requests for live captioning must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: MSI Science Club: Super Humans Unite
program_description: Join our Humboldt Park Branch Science Club as we partner with the Museum of Science and Industry to bring you a series of fun and super powered activities! Club participants will explore magnetic fields, parallel circuits, the Engineering Design Cycle, and 3D illusions. Participants will also have the opportunity to explore who they are by creating an origin story for their very own comic book super hero. Activity journals and materials for each session will be provided for registrants. Participants will also be able to connect virtually with other club members from the Back of the Yards branch.Participants are encouraged to attend all four sessions in the series. For kids ages 7 to 12.How to AttendThis event takes place in person. program_description: Need some strategies for self-care? Designed for busy parents and caregivers, this family program introduces simple breathing, relaxation and mindfulness strategies. Debra Yepa-PappanJoin us for a talk with visual artist Debra Yepa-Pappan (Jemez Pueblo/ Korean) whose digital works center on themes about her mixed-race identity. She is also the Community Engagement Coordinator for the Native American Exhibition renovation at the Field Museum. Debra discusses how through her artwork and her work at the Museum, she is committed to changing inaccurate representations of Native people and advocates for the inclusion of Native first voice and perspectives.Debra has international acclaim in the field of contemporary Native American art. She is co-founder of the newly formed Chicago based Center for Native Futures and as the Native Community Engagement Coordinator, she welcomes Native American guests to the Field Museum and facilitates their visits to collections. As an active member of the Chicago Native American community, she also serves as a liaison between the museum and the community both locally and nationally. Debra lives in her hometown Chicago with her husband, artist Chris Pappan, and their daughter Ji Hae.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Things I Wish I Knew: Holiday Stress
program_description: Join North Pulaski Adult Librarian Jenny and Wrightwood-Ashburn Teen Librarian Nate for a chat about handling holiday stress. program_name: Adult Writing and Poetry- A Writer's Thoughts
program_description: You got a story to tell, a book to write, and your thoughts are just all over the place, well let’s come together and get those thoughts onto paper. program_name: When House Ruled Chicago by Marcus Chapman
program_description: Screenwriter, music historian, author, radio personality, and TV One "Unsung" contributor Marcus Chapman will present a lecture on how a movement of music, radio, parties, fashion & cassette tapes defined the city in the 1980s and early'90s.This event is co-sponsored by CPL’s African American Heritage Committee. program_name: Learning Circle: The Art of Storytelling with Pixar
program_description: Join a multi week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. You’ll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. This course will take place virtually, and you will need free Zoom software. Registration is required. Please register for Virtual Learning Circle The Art of Storytelling with Pixar on the P2PU website for this learning course. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. program_name: Adult Reading Circle: Just Mercy with Dr. Stephanie Davenport
program_description: Join the Carter G. Woodson Reading Circle as special guest Dr. Stephanie Davenport discusses Just Mercy by Bryan Stevenson. Dr. Stephanie Davenport is an avid reader and life-long learner. In her career as an educator on site and in life, she has taught high school English in the Chicago Public Schools, founding principal of the Betty Shabazz International Charter Schools, Director of Educational Services for the DuSable Museum of African American History, an AARP Experience Corp., literacy volunteer tutor and storyteller member of ASE, the Chicago affiliate of the National Association of Black Storytellers (NABS). At all times, she keeps her reading list current using the Chicago Public Library's Monthly Staff Picks. As a trained restorative justice practitioner, her interest in social justice blends well with her examination of the concepts of race and history articulated by James Baldwin, Natasha Trethewey and Edwidge DanticatAuthor Bryan Stevenson describes Just Mercy as a powerful, bold true story about the potential for mercy to redeem us, and a clarion call to fix America’s broken system of justice — from one of the most brilliant and influential lawyers of our timeHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Please register online by 3 pm Tuesday, November 16 . You'll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. By registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines.AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4072 or email access@chipublib.org. Requests for live captioning must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

program_name: Acción Diferida para los Llegados en la Infancia (DACA)
program_description: DACA protege a los jóvenes, que vinieron a los Estados Unidos cuando eran niños, de la deportación, y proporciona autorización de trabajo, libertad condicional anticipada y mejores oportunidades de vida. Los presentadores abordarán el historial y el estado actual de DACA, así como la elegibilidad para las solicitudes iniciales y de renovación. Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. When visiting the library, maintain at least six feet of distance from staff and other patrons. Stay home if you or someone in your group are experiencing symptoms of any illness per order of the Chicago Department of Public Health.Questions about visiting the library? Check out our Using the Library FAQ.

program_name: Neighborhood Tour: Make A Joyful Sound - Chicago Plays and Plays and Plays and Sings and Plays
program_description: Music animates all corners of Chicago and the city’s beats and rhythms can be found in Jackson Park, the Green Mill, Symphony Center, and up and down Michigan Avenue. It’s been a tough time for live music as of late, of course. With that in mind, we’ll head out to talk to Chicagoans and others around the Loop to talk about how they’ve still made music a part of their lives during these times. And hey—we’re also going to hear music from Millennium Park! Join us for virtual neighborhood tours, featuring host and urbanologist Max Grinnell, as we explore the people, places and communities that make Chicago's neighborhoods so special! How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? program_name: Adult Book Discussion: This Tender Land
program_description: Join the staff of the Beverly Branch for a discussion of This Tender Land by William K. Krueger. This Tender Land tells the story of four orphans who flee a boarding school where hundreds of Native American children are forcibly separated from their parents. Set in Minnesota during the Great Depression of 1932, the orphans cross paths with a variety of people on their epic quest to find a home of their own.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom and in person. Woodson Regional Library is partnering with SHARE Network of the University of Chicago Biological Sciences by providing resources for older adults on the South Side. This support group is open for individuals who serve as caregivers for individuals with dementia. The support group will entail discussions on topics that are inspired by the interest and needs of the participating dementia-caregivers, such as daily care activities related to food and eating, communication, safety, behavior, and aggression, just to name a few.Research shows that there are too few geriatric specialists to meet the current needs of older South Side residents. The Woodson Dementia-Caregivers Support Group is designed to provide additional support for South Side residents. "Caregiver Stress Reductions Tool Kits" will be available for all participants of this session. Details for obtaining the kits will be provided in the session. Presented by Jenil Bennett, a geriatrics community health worker and Monica Long, a clinical research nurse educator, both from SHARE Network at University of Chicago.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Rapbrary Book Discussion: Decoded by Jay Z
program_description: Join CPL and the Richard M. Daley Branch as we read and discuss Decoded by Jay Z and enjoy renditions of his greatest hits from violinist Edith Yokley of the Chicago Sinfonietta's Resident Orchestra Project. We commemorate the 18th anniversary of Jay Z's the Black Album, and the 10 year anniversary of Decoded by Jay Z; a compelling work, that makes the case that Hip Hop lyrics are poetry. "Decoded is the autobiography and memoir of rapper Jay-Z, published by Random House and released November 16, 2010 on hardcover and November 1, 2011 on paperback. The book combines lyrics, their explanations, anecdotes, reflections, and autobiographical information. Jay-Z explains the three reasons why he wanted to write the book being a case for hip-hop lyrics as poetry, to tell a generational story turned into powerful experiences and revolved as a story everyone can relate to."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: A Rain of Night Birds
program_description: Join Legler Regional Library in celebrating Native American Heritage Month as we discuss A Rain of Night Birds by Deena Metzger. We will also learn about the library's historic mural “Wilderness, Winter River Scene” by Midwestern artist R. Fayerweather Babcock.Perhaps never before in the history of humankind has the disparity between Indigenous mind and Western mind been more on the pulse of what we must pay attention to in order to insure our survival. Deena Metzger has written a novel in which two people, who are from each side of this polarity, begin a loving relationship. Sandra Birdswell is a student of climatology with an uncanny ability to sense weather events. She first meets Terrence, a Native man and a professor of climatology, at her university classes. Years later, they are drawn together by the powerful forces of their love, for the Earth, for each other, and their mutual need to seek out the broken links of their family histories.How to AttendThis event takes place in person.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth n order to attend this program. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. When visiting the library, maintain at least six feet of distance from staff and other patrons. Stay home if you or someone in your group are experiencing symptoms of any illness per order of the Chicago Department of Public Health.Questions about visiting the library? Check out our Using the Library FAQ.

program_name: Author Chat and Adult Book Discussion: The Aftermath by Iris Bolling
program_description: Join the Brainerd Branch for a conversation with acclaimed African American author Iris Bolling as she discusses her latest release The Aftermath: A Nate Reigns Novel and other future projects with readers. Her latest novel is sure to take you on a wild ride of mystery and suspense. Major Crimes Division detective and one-time top criminal defense attorney, Nathan ‘Nate’ Reigns, uses his insight from his previous occupation to close his cases. His friend and mentor, Prosecuting Attorney Alex Burnett, is found dead. His death investigation ensues. The investigation leads to the discovery of other crimes which garners huge headlines for the Richmond Police Department. For the brass, the number of closed cases is a triumph, however, it does not solve the murder of Nate's friend. Nate vows justice.   This suspense thriller with a twist is sure to leave you gasping to breathe…The innocent and the guilty have to deal with the Aftermath.How to Get a Copy of the Book: You can find an electronic copy of the title on the author's website or most other online outlets where books are sold. How to Attend:This event takes place on Zoom. Canva is a robust cloud-based digital design tool that can be used to make anything from posts for social media to event flyers, and even stylized resumes.  It is a great resource if you are interested in dipping your toes into digital design in a user-friendly way.  This short class will demonstrate navigating Canva and getting started with different features and format types.  We will complete a follow-along tour followed with independent work time at the end if you'd like to test your new skills and get feedback and tips.  If you would like to follow along, please create an account on Canva.com prior to attending this virtual session.  There is a paid version, but the free version is amazing and has plenty of options for beginners to more advanced users.This event is hosted by Rachael from the Richard M. Daley Branch who enjoys digital design and exploring open source tools like Canva.How To Attend:This event takes place on Zoom. Register by Tuesday, November 16th at 5pm. Join Manning Branch for a discussion of Braiding Sweetgrass by Robin Wall Kimmerer. You can get the book at Manning Branch behind the reference desk, or on audiobook (read by the author).As a botanist, Robin Wall Kimmerer has been trained to ask questions of nature with the tools of science. As a member of the Citizen Potawatomi Nation, she embraces the notion that plants and animals are our oldest teachers. In Braiding Sweetgrass, Kimmerer brings these lenses of knowledge together to show that the  awakening of a wider ecological consciousness requires the acknowledgment and celebration of our reciprocal relationship with the rest of the living world. (Goodreads)This book discussion is a part of Native American Heritage Month. How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Before We Were Yours
program_description: The Literature & Language Book Club will discuss Before We Were Yours by Lisa Wingate. On a stormy night in 1930s Tennessee, the five Rill children are abducted from their poor but happy life on a Mississippi River shanty-boat while their mother is away giving birth to their newest sibling. They are taken to the Tennessee Children’s Home Society Orphanage where they are treated abusively until they are sold to wealthy, childless couples. Rill Foss is only 12 years old when she is stolen, and this is the tale of her lifelong quest to reunite her siblings. This story is based on a real life orphanage run by the notorious Georgia Tann from the 1920s to the 1950s. Readers who love real life scandals will be fascinated by this story which mixes fact with fiction.How to AttendCopies of this month's selection will be available 30 days prior to the event at the 7th floor Literature and Language reference desk at Harold Washington Library Center (400 South State Street, Chicago IL, 60605). This event takes place on Zoom. Register by 12:00 p.m. on Thursday, November 18. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Lady in the Lake
program_description: Join the Budlong Woods Branch for a discussion of Lady in the Lake by Laura Lippman.The New York Times bestselling author returns with a novel set in 1960s Baltimore that combines modern psychological insights with elements of classic noir. In 1966, Baltimore is a city of secrets that everyone seems to know--everyone, that is, except Madeline "Maddie" Schwartz. Last year, she was a happy, even pampered housewife. This year, she's bolted from her marriage of almost twenty years, determined to make good on her youthful ambitions to live a passionate, meaningful life.  Maddie wants to matter, to leave her mark on a swiftly changing world. Drawing on her own secrets, she helps Baltimore police find a murdered girl--assistance that leads to a job at the city's afternoon newspaper, the Star. Working at the newspaper offers Maddie the opportunity to make her name, and she has found just the story to do it: a missing black woman whose body was discovered in the fountain of a city park lake.  --PublisherHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Anne Shimojima's Sakura Tales; Stories from Japan
program_description: Anne Shimojima, a third generation Japanese American, has been sharing traditional Japanese folk tales for over thirty years. We invite you to listen to eleven of these - Sakura Tales; Stories from Japan - in an hour long program for teens and adults hosted by the Asian American and Pacific Islander Committee. Sakura is the Japanese word for cherry blossom.Folk tales are often forgotten as we grow older. Revisiting and remembering them is a gateway to novel and more enriching experiences and is a beautiful way to commemorate and rekindle the past. By telling the Sakura Tales, Shimojima can feel the connection to her great-grandparents' silkworm farm in Nagano-ken, and she honors the memory of her immigrant grandparents, whose spirit of gaman (perseverance) helped them survive life in a new land. Anne became a professional storyteller in 1982. She taught graduate courses in storytelling for National-Louis University and for eight years served on the board of the Wild Onion Storytelling Festival in Chicago. She is a member of the National Storytelling Network, the Northlands Storytelling Network, and Illinois Storytelling, Inc.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Adult Book Club: We Were the Lucky Ones
program_description: Join the Merlo Branch Adult Book Club for a discussion of We Were the Lucky Ones by Georgia Hunter."It is the spring of 1939, and three generations of the Kurc family are doing their best to live normal lives, even as the shadow of war grows ever closer. The talk around the family Seder table is of new babies and budding romance, not of the increasing hardships facing Jews in their hometown of Radom, Poland. But soon the horrors overtaking Europe will become inescapable and the Kurc family will be flung to the far corners of the earth, each desperately trying to chart his or her own path toward safety."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Film Discussion: The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson (2017)
program_description: This month, please watch the documentary The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson, then join us for a discussion. The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson | Official Trailer [HD] | NetflixWatch The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson on Netflix: https://www.netflix.com/title/...David France’s The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson is a deeply compelling look at the murder of a transgender legend, known as “the Rosa Parks of the LGBT movement.” The powerful, haunting film is France’s follow-up to his Academy Award® nominated How to Survive a Plague. Public Square Films present the Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson; Joy A. Tomchin and Sara Ramirez (Grey’s Anatomy) served as executive producers; L.A. Teodosio produced. Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. program_name: Born in Humboldt Park Poetry Workshop & Open Mic with Eduardo Arocho
program_description: Acclaimed poet and lifelong Humboldt Park resident Eduardo Arocho will teach a short writing workshop that will help participants translate their unique cultural heritage into poetry. Eduardo Arocho is a poet and the publisher of Bobbin Lace Press launched in 2017.  He is the author of six chapbooks of poetry and his poems have appeared in We Are by The Chicago Community Trust, Cantalogia I: El Amor (Palabra Pura Poets) by Pandora Lobo Estepario Press, Chicago, El CENTRO JOURNAL, Center for Puerto Rican Studies at Hunter College, New York, NY, Power Lines: Anthology by Tia Chucha Press, and Open Fist: Anthology of Young Illinois Poets by Tia Chucha Press. As a translator he performed two poems for the Brooks in Translation: A Gwendolyn Brooks Centennial Celebration at the Harold Washington Library in Chicago. Arocho was a featured poet at the 2016 Gerald Manley Hopkins International Poetry Festival in Kildare, Ireland. He is currently completing work on his forthcoming poetry manuscript, Nació Maestro. This event is co-sponsored by CPL’s Poetry Committee.How to Attend:This workshops will be presented virtually online. You will need to download free Zoom software. Advance registration is required. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4072 or email access@chipublib.org. Requests for live captioning must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Learning Circle: The Art of Storytelling with Pixar
program_description: Join a multi week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. You’ll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. This course will take place virtually, and you will need free Zoom software. Registration is required. Please register for Virtual Learning Circle The Art of Storytelling with Pixar on the P2PU website for this learning course. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4072 or email access@chipublib.org. Requests for live captioning must be made at least 14 business days before the eventThis event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. program_name: Rapbrary Book Discussion: Decoded by Jay Z
program_description: Join CPL and the Richard M. Daley Branch as we read and discuss Decoded by Jay Z and enjoy renditions of his greatest hits from violinist Edith Yokley of the Chicago Sinfonietta's Resident Orchestra Project. We commemorate the 18th anniversary of Jay Z's the Black Album, and the 10 year anniversary of Decoded by Jay Z; a compelling work, that makes the case that Hip Hop lyrics are poetry. "Decoded is the autobiography and memoir of rapper Jay-Z, published by Random House and released November 16, 2010 on hardcover and November 1, 2011 on paperback. The book combines lyrics, their explanations, anecdotes, reflections, and autobiographical information. Jay-Z explains the three reasons why he wanted to write the book being a case for hip-hop lyrics as poetry, to tell a generational story turned into powerful experiences and revolved as a story everyone can relate to."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: There There by Tommy Orange
program_description: Celebrating Native American Heritage Month, Pullman Branch Library will discuss There There by Tommy Orange. One of the New York Times' 10 Best Books of 2019, There There follows twelve characters from Native communities as they travel to the Big Oakland Powwow.  Poignant, unflinching, and unforgettable, There There has been hailed as an instant, multi-generational classic.How to AttendThis is an in person event. The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. When visiting the library, maintain at least six feet of distance from staff and other patrons. Check out our Events FAQs.

program_name: Silver Screen Classics: Arsenic and Old Lace (1944)
program_description: Mortimer Brewster (Cary Grant), a writer who has an aversion tomarriage falls for girl-next-door Elaine Harper (Priscilla Lane), and marry onHalloween. When the newlyweds return to deliver the news, a small celebrationis planned by his eccentric aunts, Abby (Josephine Hull), Martha(Jean Adair), and Teddy, (John Alexander), Mortimer’s brother who believes heis Theodore Roosevelt.While looking in the window seat for notes to hisnext book, Mortimer discovers a body hidden there. To cap off thisnight of mayhem, brother Jonathan Brewster (Raymond Massey), on the run fromthe law, arrives with his personal plastic surgeon, Dr. Hermann Einstein (PeterLorie). They have also brought a “guest”, Mr. Spinoza who ends up in the windowseat.How long will these uninvited guests stay? What other secrets do the Brewster sisters have? And will Mortimer and Elaine ever leave on their honeymoon? With Director Frank Capra at the helm, Arsenic and Old Lace is classic comedic theater.© Warner Bros.- 118 minute -Rated NR

This month, the African American Heritage Committee is hosting an adult book discussion for CPL's One Book One Chicago selection, Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May.After fourteen years in prison, Gerald “Stew Pot” Reeves, age thirty-one, returns home to live with his mom in Parkland, a black middle-class neighborhood on Chicago’s South Side. A frightening delinquent before being sent away (his infamies included butchering a neighbor’s cat, torching another neighbor’s garage, and terrorizing the locals with a scary pit bull named Hitler), his return sends Parkland residents into a religiously infused tailspin, which only increases when Stew Pot announces that he experienced a religious awakening in prison. Most neighbors are skeptical of this claim, with one notable exception: Mrs. Motley, a widowed retiree, and the Reeves’s next-door neighbor who loans Stew Pot a Bible, which is seen by Stew Pot and many in the community as a friendly gesture (Goodreads, 2021). How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. program_name: The Visual Record: An Introduction to the South Side Home Movie Project
program_description: Home movies capture a range of details about everyday neighborhood life in Chicago, from fashion to food to the ways people walk down the street. They also provide unique evidence of the ways in which people represent themselves on camera, precursors to the “selfies” of today. Join the South Side Home Movie Project for an introduction to this unique initiative to collect, preserve, digitize and exhibit amateur films from Chicago’s South Side neighborhoods. Featuring film clips from the 1920s-1980s, this session invites attendees to imagine new ways of activating and preserving community knowledge through home movies.  Families who have donated their films to the SSHMP will be on hand to narrate their films and share the experience of preserving their home movies and seeing them on screen for the first time in decades.How to Attend:This event will be presented virtually online. You will need to download free Zoom software. Advance registration is required. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4072 or email access@chipublib.org. Requests for live captioning must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Learning Circle: The Art of Storytelling with Pixar
program_description: Join a multi week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. You’ll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. This course will take place virtually, and you will need free Zoom software. Registration is required. Please register for Virtual Learning Circle The Art of Storytelling with Pixar on the P2PU website for this learning course. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. program_description: Let's discuss the memoir Hunger by the award winning, critically acclaimed author Roxane Gay."Gay has written ... about food and bodies, using her own emotional and psychological struggles as a means of exploring our shared anxieties over pleasure, consumption, appearance, and health. As a woman who describes her own body as 'wildly undisciplined,' Roxane understands the tension between desire and denial, between self-comfort and self-care"--Amazon.com.You can check out Hunger: A Memoir of (my) Body at your favorite Chicago Public Library branch by placing a hold request or at the Richard M. Maker-in-Residence Faith Humphrey Hill is teaching and developing a community art piece in the Maker Lab. Drop by during her residency hours to learn about machine knitting, mixed media portraiture, drawing, and her project which will be on display early next year.Faith Humphrey Hill received a BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Masters in Arts Management from Columbia College. For 20 years, she helped others discover and make art daily through leadership positions in galleries, museums, and community arts organizations. In 2015, she gave art-making her full attention through her website dartily [dartily=art+daily]. In this process, she began creating the artwork she is best known for: portrait artwork that combines drawing and knitting with digital tools. Learn more at dartily and on Instagram @dartily_faith.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. program_name: Reading Came First Book Club: The Great Believers
program_description: Join us as we honor the many lives lost to the AIDS Crisis during December, read and discuss The Great Believers by Rebecca Makkai."In 1985, Yale Tishman, the development director for a Chicago art gallery, is about to pull off a coup, bringing an extraordinary collection of 1920s paintings. Yet as his career begins to flourish, the carnage of the AIDs epidemic grows around him. One by one, his friends are dying and after his friend Nico’s funeral, the virus circles closer and closer to Yale himself. Soon the only person he has left is Fiona, Nico’s little sister.Thirty years later, Fiona is in Paris tracking down her estranged daughter who disappeared into a cult. While staying with an old friend, a famous photographer who documented the Chicago epidemic, she finds herself finally grappling with the devastating ways the AIDS crisis affected her life and her relationship with her daughter. Yale and Fiona’s intertwining stories take us through the heartbreak of 80’s and the chaos of the modern world, as both struggle to find goodness in the midst of disaster."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: The Art of Storytelling: A Learning Circle
program_description: How would you tell the story of your community? Join a four part course to learn the tools of the storytelling trade and write your own original play, short story, or narrative poem! We will cover a new topic each week, focusing on point-of-view and story arc, characters and description, style, and editing. This course will take place virtually and in-person. In-person capacity is limited to six learners. Registration is required and COVID-19 safety protocols will be followed. program_description: Join Albany Park Branch's book club as we discuss 2021 OBOC title, Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. Gerald "Stew Pot" Reeves returns home from prison to live with his mom on Chicago's South Side. program_name: Season Finale: Eric Charles May, author of Bedrock Faith, interviewed by Donna Seaman
program_description: Celebrate the season finale of One Book, One Chicago’s 20th year with a very special conversation. Eric Charles May, author of Bedrock Faith, joins Booklist Editor Donna Seaman for a conversation about his writing, the book, and Chicago as a character. Eric Charles May is an associate professor in the Fiction Writing at Columbia College Chicago. A Chicago native and former reporter for the Washington Post, his fiction has appeared in the magazines Fish Stories, F, and Criminal Class. In addition to his Post reporting, his nonfiction has appeared in Sport Literate, the Chicago Tribune, and the personal essay anthology Briefly Knocked Unconscious by a Low-Flying Duck. Bedrock Faith, the 2021 One Book, One Chicago selection, is his first novel.How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. You'll be able to ask questions during the event as well!Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.AccessibilityAutomatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Adult Classics Book Club: The Talented Mr. Ripley
program_description: The Lincoln Park Branch's Adult Classics Book Club will discuss Patricia Highsmith's The Talented Mr. Ripley.In a chilling literary hall of mirrors, Patricia Highsmith introduces Tom Ripley.  Like a hero in a latter-day Henry James novel, he is sent to Italy with a commission to coax a prodigal young American back to his wealthy father. But Ripley finds himself very fond of Dickie Greenleaf. He wants to be like him--exactly like him.  Suave, agreeable, and utterly amoral, Ripley stops at nothing--certainly not only one murder--to accomplish his goal.  Turning the mystery form inside out, Highsmith shows the terrifying abilities afforded to a man unhindered by the concept of evil.Copies are available at Lincoln Park's Circulation Desk.How to Attend:This event takes place on Zoom. Please register by November 30, 2021. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. Join us as we discuss The Tiger by John Vaillant.  Deep in the evergreen woods of the Siberian Taiga, there roams a beast whose prowess and ferocity rivals that of the fictional Great White shark, Jaws. This is The Tiger—a half-ton, eight-feet long, apex predator who has developed a taste for the humans living in this remote wilderness. After a series of maulings, the villagers call for help is answered by Yuri Trush and his team of tiger inspectors. Now the hunt is on and author John Vaillant takes the reader along every step of the way, from the snow-packed tiger tracks winding through the largest boreal forest on Earth to the echoic halls of the Kremlin, looking for answers to questions about deforestation, natural law, and perhaps the most important: Where and when will The Tiger strike next?Copies of this month's selection will be available 30 days prior to the event at the 6th floor reference desk at Harold Washington Library Center (400 South State Street, Chicago IL, 60605).How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register by 12 p.m. on Thursday, December 2. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Author Jacquelin Thomas Discusses The Prodigal Book Series
program_description: Jacquelin Thomas is an award-winning, best-selling author with 85+ published titles. A few of her recent releases are: Return to Me,  Another Chance With You, and Jezebel. She has published in the romance, women’s fiction, inspirational and young adult genres. Her books have garnered several awards, including two EMMA awards, the Romance In Color Reviewers Award, Readers Choice Award and the Atlanta Choice Award in the Religious & Spiritual category. Jacquelin was a 2005 honoree at the Houston Black Film Festival for the movie adaptation of her novel, Hidden Blessings. She was the first recipient to receive the Writers Achievement Award at the North Carolina Book Festival in Winston-Salem. She also received a Lifetime Achievement Award from Romantic Times Magazine. Jacquelin will discuss The Prodigal Series: The Prodigal Husband, Defining Moments, and Unexpected Serenity (available September 30, 2021).How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Graphic Novel Book Group: The Secret to Superhuman Strength
program_description: Welcome to the Logan Square Branch Graphic Novel Book Club! Books are available at the Logan Square Branch Circulation Desk.Join us as we read and discuss Alison Bechdel's The Secret to Superhuman Strength."As a kid, Bechdel ordered a pamphlet with this book's title from an ad in a comic book. It was a complete disappointment, but she was no less convinced that the secret existed and that she would find it. Divided into the decades of her life, this graphic memoir is as much a cultural history of the last half-century as it is Bechdel's story of pursuing physical strength, which it turns out is not so different from surrendering to her art. 'When my mind shuts up and my body takes over, I'm outside the dualistic framework of language.'" --BooklistHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Reading Came First Book Club: The Great Believers
program_description: Join us as we honor the many lives lost to the AIDS Crisis during December, read and discuss The Great Believers by Rebecca Makkai."In 1985, Yale Tishman, the development director for a Chicago art gallery, is about to pull off a coup, bringing an extraordinary collection of 1920s paintings. Yet as his career begins to flourish, the carnage of the AIDs epidemic grows around him. One by one, his friends are dying and after his friend Nico’s funeral, the virus circles closer and closer to Yale himself. Soon the only person he has left is Fiona, Nico’s little sister.Thirty years later, Fiona is in Paris tracking down her estranged daughter who disappeared into a cult. While staying with an old friend, a famous photographer who documented the Chicago epidemic, she finds herself finally grappling with the devastating ways the AIDS crisis affected her life and her relationship with her daughter. Yale and Fiona’s intertwining stories take us through the heartbreak of 80’s and the chaos of the modern world, as both struggle to find goodness in the midst of disaster."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Join us for a screening of Home Alone. A mischievous 8-year-old who's picked on by his older siblings and ignored by his parents would really rather be left alone—and that's exactly what happens when he gets accidentally left behind in a frenzied rush to the airport for a family vacation in Paris over the holiday season. After learning to fend for himself, the boy has to protect his house against two bumbling burglars who are planning to rob it.© Twentieth Century Fox – 102 minutes – Rated PGCommunity Cinema is at a branch near you! Check out other screenings at libraries across Chicago.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. Check out our Using the Library FAQ.

program_name: Grab and Go: Embroidery Hoop State Art
program_description: Did you know Illinois is bordered by the Mississippi River, Ohio River and Wabash River? Ponder the common thread with the Embroidery Hoop State Art. Looking for a fun creative outlet? Come pick up a fun arts and crafts grab and go kit to take home courtesy of the Maker Lab and the Arts & Music Department! This grab and go kit is available at the 8th floor reference desk during library hours until December 31st or while supplies last. This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

A librarian from CPL's Northside Neighborhood History Collection shares materials from the Ravenswood Lake View Community Collection that depicts daily life during the fledgling years of this village. Highlights include 1886 Snyder Map of Lake View Township and photos of early residents and businesses. Tune in for a special series of videos featuring archival material related to Chicago’s neighborhoods. CPL archivists and librarians showcase secrets and treasures from the archives that highlight our city’s history.  How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.AccessibilityAutomatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Get to Work with the ICNC
program_description: Create a new resume, update an outdated resume, and discover job opportunities through the Industrial Council of Nearwest Chicago (ICNC). ICNC can refer individuals to job training providers and small business resources.In addition, the ICNC is a partner of The Hatchery Chicago. Together they offer a culinary training program for young adults. ICNC works with start-ups and established businesses in industries such as manufacturing, food/beverage, apparel/textiles and more.How to AttendThis is an in person event.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. program_description: Join the Kelly Branch for a discussion of Mr. Ives' Christmas by Oscar Hijuelos."The Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love now writes a haunting story of a man reflecting upon his life through the lens of Christmases past. program_name: Reading Came First Book Club: The Great Believers
program_description: Join us as we honor the many lives lost to the AIDS Crisis during December, read and discuss The Great Believers by Rebecca Makkai."In 1985, Yale Tishman, the development director for a Chicago art gallery, is about to pull off a coup, bringing an extraordinary collection of 1920s paintings. Yet as his career begins to flourish, the carnage of the AIDs epidemic grows around him. One by one, his friends are dying and after his friend Nico’s funeral, the virus circles closer and closer to Yale himself. Soon the only person he has left is Fiona, Nico’s little sister.Thirty years later, Fiona is in Paris tracking down her estranged daughter who disappeared into a cult. While staying with an old friend, a famous photographer who documented the Chicago epidemic, she finds herself finally grappling with the devastating ways the AIDS crisis affected her life and her relationship with her daughter. Yale and Fiona’s intertwining stories take us through the heartbreak of 80’s and the chaos of the modern world, as both struggle to find goodness in the midst of disaster."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Do you love movies and books? During our Pages & Popcorn events, you can discuss the movie, book, or both! Passing is adapted from the celebrated 1929 novel  Passing by Nella Larsen. The film tells the story of two Black women, Irene Redfield (Tessa Thompson) and Clare Kendry (Academy Award nominee Ruth Negga), who can "pass" as white but choose to live on opposite sides of the color line during the height of the Harlem Renaissance in late 1920s New York.After a chance encounter reunites the former childhood friends one summer afternoon, Irene reluctantly allows Clare into her home, where she ingratiates herself to Irene's husband (André Holland) and family, and soon her larger social circle as well. As their lives become more deeply intertwined, Irene finds her once-steady existence upended by Clare, and PASSING becomes a riveting examination of obsession, repression, and the lies people tell themselves and others to protect their carefully constructed realities.Watch Passing, only on Netflix: https://www.netflix.com/title/...SUBSCRIBE: http://bit.ly/29qBUt7How to Attend the Discussion:This discussion takes place on Zoom. program_name: Book Discussion: Confessions of an Ugly Stepsister by Gregory Maguire
program_description: Join us as we discuss Confessions of An Ugly Stepsister by Gregory Maguire. We all have heard the story of Cinderella, the beautiful child cast out to slave among the ashes. But, what about her stepsisters? The homely pair exiled into ignominy by the fame of their lovely sibling? Author Gregory Maguire invites the reader to hear the other side of the story, the story of the ugly stepsister.Copies of the book are available at the Budlong Woods Branch circulation desk.How to Attend:This event takes place on Zoom. Please register by sending an e-mail to, or visiting, the Budlong Woods Branch by Thursday, December 16th. You will receive an email with a Zoom meeting link about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Adult Book Club: The Starless Sea
program_description: Join the Merlo Branch Adult Book Club for a discussion of The Starless Sea by Erin Morgentern."Zachary Ezra Rawlins is a graduate student in Vermont when he discovers a rare book hidden in the stacks. As he turns the pages, entranced by tales of lovelorn prisoners, key collectors, and nameless acolytes, he reads something strange: a story from his own childhood. Bewildered by this inexplicable book and desperate to make sense of how his own life came to be recorded, Zachary uncovers a series of clues--a bee, a key, and a sword--that lead him to a masquerade party in New York, to a secret club, and through a doorway to a subterranean library, hidden far below the surface of the earth. What Zachary finds in this curious place is more than just a buried home for books and their guardians--it is a place of lost cities and seas of honey, lovers who pass notes under doors and across time, and of stories whispered by the dead. Zachary learns of those who have sacrificed much to protect this realm, relinquishing their sight and their tongues to preserve this archive, and also those who are intent on its destruction. Together with Mirabel, a fierce, pink-haired protector of the place, and Dorian, a beautiful barefoot man with shifting alliances, Zachary travels the twisting tunnels, darkened stairwells, crowded ballrooms, and sweetly-soaked shores of this magical world, discovering his purpose--in both the rare book and in his own life."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Reading Came First Book Club: The Great Believers
program_description: Join us as we honor the many lives lost to the AIDS Crisis during December, read and discuss The Great Believers by Rebecca Makkai."In 1985, Yale Tishman, the development director for a Chicago art gallery, is about to pull off a coup, bringing an extraordinary collection of 1920s paintings. Yet as his career begins to flourish, the carnage of the AIDs epidemic grows around him. One by one, his friends are dying and after his friend Nico’s funeral, the virus circles closer and closer to Yale himself. Soon the only person he has left is Fiona, Nico’s little sister.Thirty years later, Fiona is in Paris tracking down her estranged daughter who disappeared into a cult. While staying with an old friend, a famous photographer who documented the Chicago epidemic, she finds herself finally grappling with the devastating ways the AIDS crisis affected her life and her relationship with her daughter. Yale and Fiona’s intertwining stories take us through the heartbreak of 80’s and the chaos of the modern world, as both struggle to find goodness in the midst of disaster."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Grab and Go: Embroidery Hoop State Art
program_description: Did you know Illinois is bordered by the Mississippi River, Ohio River and Wabash River? Ponder the common thread with the Embroidery Hoop State Art. Looking for a fun creative outlet? Come pick up a fun arts and crafts grab and go kit to take home courtesy of the Maker Lab and the Arts & Music Department! This grab and go kit is available at the 8th floor reference desk during library hours until December 31st or while supplies last. This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Cook by the Book Discussion: Hero Dinners
program_description: Do you enjoy browsing through cookbooks? Do you love trying new dishes? Are you looking for new recipes to wow your family and friends? Then grab your apron for this cookbook club! Edgebrook Library will discuss Hero Dinners by Marge Perry and David Bonom. Copies of the book will be available at Edgebrook Library's reference desk starting on 12/11/21. Check out the book and select a recipe or two to make at home. Then we'll meet in the community room to discuss what we cooked.How to AttendThis event takes place in person.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover the nose and mouth in order to attend this program. If you do not have a mask, we will provide you with a disposable mask.Stay home if you or someone in your group are experiencing symptoms of any illness per order of the Chicago Department of Public Health.Questions about visiting the library? A librarian with a notary stamp will be providing one hour of free notary services. All patrons needing an item notarized must bring with them a valid and unexpired State ID, Drivers License, or Matricula Consular. A maximum of 2 items or pages will be notarized per individual.Please note that only standard notary services will be offered, no legal advice or counsel will be provided!Do you also need to laminate something but don’t have access to a laminator? We will have 2 laminators on hand for you to use and a limited quantity of laminating sheets on hand. You can even bring in your own laminating sheets if you have multiple documents to seal. Any brand of laminating sheet will work. 3 mil or 5 mil only. You can do full sheets, partial sheets, or name tag sizes as well.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. CPL staff wear masks at all times.When visiting the library, maintain at least six feet of distance from staff and other patrons. Stay home if you or someone in your group are experiencing symptoms of any illness per order of the Chicago Department of Public Health.Questions about visiting the library? Check out our Using the Library FAQ.

program_description: This month, South Chicago Branch will read Miseducated by Brandon P. Fleming.Through his personal narrative, readers witness Fleming's personal transformation, self-education, and how he takes what he learns about words and power to help others like himself. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks. CPL staff wear masks at all times.When visiting the library, maintain at least six feet of distance from staff and other patrons. Stay home if you or someone in your group are experiencing symptoms of any illness per order of the Chicago Department of Public Health.Questions about visiting the library? Check out our Using the Library FAQ.

This month, we're reading Deacon King Kong by James McBride.In September 1969, a fumbling, cranky old church deacon known as Sportcoat shuffles into the courtyard of the Cause Houses housing project in south Brooklyn, pulls a .38 from his pocket, and in front of everybody shoots the project's drug dealer at point-blank range.In Deacon King Kong, McBride brings to vivid life the people affected by the shooting: the victim, the African-American and Latinx residents who witnessed it, the white neighbors, the local cops assigned to investigate, the members of the Five Ends Baptist Church where Sportcoat was a deacon, the neighborhood's Italian mobsters, and Sportcoat himself. (Goodreads, 2021). How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. You'll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. By registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines. This event uses a third-party website and may be hosted by an organization CPL has partnered with. We recommend you review the privacy policies of any third-party sites before providing them with any personal data. For more information, please see our Website Privacy Statement.Questions about attending online events? Check out our Events FAQs. AccessibilityAutomatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4072 or email access@chipublib.org. Requests for live captioning must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

program_name: Get to Work with the ICNC
program_description: Create a new resume, update an outdated resume, and discover job opportunities through the Industrial Council of Nearwest Chicago (ICNC). ICNC can refer individuals to job training providers and small business resources.In addition, the ICNC is a partner of The Hatchery Chicago. Together they offer a culinary training program for young adults. ICNC works with start-ups and established businesses in industries such as manufacturing, food/beverage, apparel/textiles and more.How to AttendThis is an in person event.The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority.
